org.dyn4j.geometry.decompose

Class SweepLine

  • java.lang.Object
    • org.dyn4j.geometry.decompose.SweepLine
  • All Implemented Interfaces:
    Decomposer

    public class SweepLine
extends java.lang.Object
implements Decomposer
    Performs the Sweep Line algorithm to decompose the given polygon into y-monotone pieces which are then used to triangulate the original polygon.

    This algorithm is O(n log n) complexity in the y-monotone decomposition phase and O(n) in the triangulation phase yielding a total complexity of O(n log n).

    After triangulation, the Hertel-Mehlhorn algorithm is used to reduce the number of convex pieces. This is performed in O(n) time.

    This algorithm total complexity is O(n log n).

    Since:
    2.2.0
    Version:
    3.0.2
    Author:
    William Bittle

    • Nested Class Summary

      Nested Classes 
      Modifier and Type Class and Description
      protected static class  SweepLine.Edge
      Represents an edge of a polygon storing the next and previous edges and the vertices that make up this edge.
      protected static class  SweepLine.EdgeBinaryTree
      Class to extend the BinarySearchTree to add a method for finding the SweepLine.Edge closest to a given SweepLine.Vertex.
      protected static class  SweepLine.Vertex
      Represents a vertex on a polygon that stores information about the left and right edges and left and right vertices.

      • initialize

        protected java.util.PriorityQueue<SweepLine.Vertex> initialize(Vector2[] points,
                                                   DoublyConnectedEdgeList dcel)
        Returns a priority queue of the points in the given array.

        This method also builds the cyclic doubly-linked list of vertices and edges used to neighbor features in constant time.

        Parameters:
        points - the array of polygon points
        dcel - the DCEL object to add references to the priority queue vertices
        Returns:
        PriorityQueue<SweepLine.Vertex>

      • isBelow

        protected boolean isBelow(Vector2 p,
              Vector2 q)
        Returns true if the given point p is below the given point q.

        If the point p and q form a horizontal line then p is considered below if its x coordinate is greater than q's x coordinate.

        Parameters:
        p - the point
        q - another point
        Returns:
        boolean true if p is below q; false if p is above q
